questionnaire.description: Security is a wide-spread topic that covers many aspects of a companies infrastructure. It involves onboarding and offboarding of access rights, password management, and access monitoring. This coach introduces you to best-practices on login management and profit from rich material to learn more about industry standards.

question.text: Do you have an IT security baseline?

option.text: Yes, we do
No, we don't
We don't know what that is
Yes, we have full automation
Yes, we automate some aspects
No, we do the entire user creation manually

question.text: Do you provision access during user creation?

option.text: Yes, we apply permission during user creation
No, this is done seperately

question.text: Do you distribute access privileges based on roles or groups?

option.text: Yes, all logins, file access and physical restrictions are based on roles
Yes, all logins and file access are based on roles
No, all access is given individually

question.text: Do you apply the same logical controls for all systems?

option.text: Yes, all systems are equally sealed off
No, each system is secured to its appropriate required degree of security

question.text: Which of the following authentication methods do you use on sensitive systems?

option.text: 2 Factor authentication
Biometric devices
Physical keys
Digital keys
PIN entry pads

instruction.text:
Makes it harder to get into your account! Passwords are one way of authentication while there are other forms of verifying users’ identity such as fingerprints, 2/multiple-factor authentication (2FA), applying hardware or software tokens, or smart cards which you can add extra security layer.

More info ...

Why 2FA!  Even strong passwords cannot protect you against data breaches or key logger attacks. Key logging programs can track all your keystrokes including your account credentials.

More info ...

Activate dual-factor authentication for your significant accounts such as emails.

How to enable 2FA! Some websites and services offer 2FA sometimes with different names. You need to enable it. Second factors can usually be received by SMS or in an authentication app (unique one-time access code).

Authentication can be in the form of: a PIN you know, a phone you have, a biometric such as a fingerprint.

Google Authenticator is one of the popular and easy to use apps for 2FA.

More info ...

question.text: Do you implement the principle of least privilege?

option.text: Yes, we strictly adhere to the principle in every system
Yes, however there are some exceptions
No, more than half of our systems provide too much access for the job required

question.text: Do you enforce a password policy?

option.text: Yes, we set a policy for passwords and make sure it is enforced
We do have a password policy but don't enforce it
No, our employees may freely choose their password

question.text: Do you force users to use strong passwords?

option.text: Yes, we force all users to use strong passwords
Yes, our password policy requires decent password strength
No, our users may use passwords considered to be insecure
NO, WE DID NOT ASK USERS TO USE STRONG PASSWORDS

instruction.text:
Avoid predictable passwords! Strong password (considering minimum requirements) is fundamental to protect against Dictionary Attacks or Password Guessing. Many people tend to select a single word or short password and it is predictable in a short period.

More info ...

Turn on Password Protection! 63% of small business cyber breaches occurred because of weak or stolen passwords.

More info ...

Meet certain criteria when you manage a password! Password strength is not the same as the password length. A password should be meaningful (so memorable) to you but difficult (cryptic) to guess for the others (or specialized software).

  • Strong passwords: Have at least 8 characters, Contain both upper and lower case, Have at least one numerical character, Have at least one special character 
  • Do not write down passwords on sticky notes
  • Create a cryptic password.

How to solve the memory problem?

  • Apply Passphrase instead of Password: First, make an easy to remember phrase, then select the first character of each word, then use upper/lower case and finally, you can exchange special characters by numbers.
  • Apply Password Managers: You can have a master password to save long, complex passwords

More info ...

Check if your Password is strong enough!

Check if your account was compromised (Swiss)!

question.text: Do you have a user and service account repository?

option.text: Yes, we use a database that saves all user accounts
No, we don't have a repository

question.text: Do you track local accounts on relevant system?

option.text: Yes, we keep track of local accounts
No, we don't have an overview of local accounts

question.text: Do you clear access permission during offboarding of employees?

option.text: Yes, we immediately clear during offboarding
Yes, we clear access after a 1 to 3 months after employee leave
No, we don't strictly revoke access

question.text: Do you rotate SSH keys after an employee leaves?

option.text: Yes, we revoke SSH keys of users
Yes, we clear SSH keys after the employee leaves
No, we don't revoke SSH keys

question.text: Do you review access permissions of users?

option.text: YES, we review permissions regularly
Yes, we review permissions occassionaly
No, we never check permissions

question.text: Do you log access attempts to relevant systems?

option.text: Yes, we log access attempts
No, we don't log access attempts

question.text: Do you monitor the network for unusual traffic?

option.text: Yes, we monitor the network
No, we don't monitor the network

question.text: Do you have a remote access policy?

option.text: Yes, we do have a remote access policy
No, we don't have a remote access policy
